qas.question: Why is Captain Fritz Joubert Duquesne famous?
After Duquesne made his way to St. George, what did he do?

answers.text: stowed away on a boat heading to Baltimore, Maryland

qas.question: After settling in the US, what did Duquesne do?

answers.text: became a spy for Germany in both World Wars

plausible_answers.text: conspiracy against the British government and on (the charge of) espionage

qas.question: What was Captain Joubert Fritz Duquesne serving a sentence for?
What sentence was Captain Joubert Fritz Duquesne serving?

plausible_answers.text: Col. Duquesne was arrested by the FBI for leading the Duquesne Spy Ring

context: The <a0_0>most famous escapee<a0_0/> was the Boer prisoner of war Captain Fritz Joubert Duquesne who was serving a <b4_0>life sentence<b4_0/> for "<b3_0>conspiracy against the British government and on (the charge of) espionage<b3_0/>.". On the night of 25 June 1902, <b5_0>Duquesne<b5_0/> slipped out of his tent, worked his way over a barbed-wire fence, swam 1.5 miles (2.4 km) past patrol boats and bright spot lights, through storm-wracked, shark infested waters, using a distant lighthouse for navigation until he arrived ashore on the main island. From there he escaped to the port of St. George's and a week later, he <a1_0>stowed away on a boat heading to Baltimore, Maryland<a1_0/>. He settled in the US and later <a2_0>became a spy for Germany in both World Wars<a2_0/>. In 1942, <b6_0>Col. Duquesne was arrested by the FBI for leading the Duquesne Spy Ring<b6_0/>, which still to this day the largest espionage case in the history of the United States.
